You need to grant the manager access to the Microsoft Teams Call Quality Dashboard.
Which role should you assign to the manager?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct
The Support Specialist role is the least amount of priviliges of the 4 choices. It gives access to CQD and lets the manager view reports
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/turning-on-and-using-call-quality-dashboard#assign-admin-roles-for-access-to-cqd
we should follow the principle of least privilege here, so It's Teams Communications Support Specialist

questions.question_text:
You need to resolve the partner company communication issue.
Which two PowerShell commands should you run? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Why would C be the answer? Skype is already setup and the question says it's a Teams issue not a Skype on-premise issue. Going with AD

Boys and girls, it stated: The company currently uses "Skype for Business SERVER (SfB) as a collaboration tool." and company wants to migrate to Teams.
B: Set-CsTenantFederationConfiguration - is for Skype for Bus Online - u see (wont happen)
C: correct - link - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/skypeforbusiness/manage/federation-and-external-access/access-edge/enable-or-disable-federation-and-public-im-connectivity#to-enable-federation-and-public-im-connectivity

Selected Answer: AB
AB imho
C is for the partner company's SfB OnPrem servers, out of scope for us

Enable or disable federation and public IM connectivity in Skype for Business Server - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/skypeforbusiness/manage/federation-and-external-access/access-edge/enable-or-disable-federation-and-public-im-connectivity

Selected Answer: AC
On-premises only (as per case study, SfB (not SkB Online)
In on-premises tools:
- Ensure federation is enabled in CsAccessEdgeConfiguration.
- Ensure federation for the user is enabled through ExternalAccessPolicy (either through the global policy, site policy, or user assigned policy).
- If you are not using open federation, ensure the target domain is listed in AllowedDomains.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-external-access

B is used for Skype for business online - Set-CsTenantFederationConfiguration - Manages federation configuration settings for your Skype for Business Online tenants. These settings are used to determine which domains (if any) your users are allowed to communicate with.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/powershell/module/skype/set-cstenantfederationconfiguration?view=skype-ps

Selected Answer: AB
Problem:
The company does a lot of business with the following partner companies. Contoso employees are not able to communicate with these partners by using Microsoft Teams.

Skype onprem is working and is not in scope here.

We need to configure in the tenant the external access policy (A) and add the partners domain to the allowed list (B).

Selected Answer: AB
External access is an issue while using Teams so we would need to use set-cstenantfederationconfiguration as the command is relevant to Teams

questions.question_text:
You need to configure the system to meet the requirements for guest users.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Messaging policies:
Messaging policies are used to control what chat and channel messaging features are available to users in Teams. You can use the Global (Org-wide default) policy or create one or more custom messaging policies for "people in your organization"

Where do you see GUEST? lol

Calling policies: 
Calling policies are used to control what calling features are available to people in Teams. You can use the Global (Org-wide default) policy and customize it or create one or more custom calling policies for "people that have phone numbers in your organization"

There is no calling policy for guest, because there is NO phone number for guest lol
Are we all looking under Security Requirements for guest?

Selected Answer: BC
You can't assign a policy to guest users. Also, Guest Access Settings covers both requirements, hence BC

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/configure-troubleshoot-microsoft-teams-clients-services/7-troubleshoot-voice?ns-enrollment-type=learningpath&ns-enrollment-id=learn.wwl.troubleshoot-microsoft-365-teams

comments.content:
The policies cannot be assigned to guest users, the only thing you can do is to adjust Guest access settings, even if it is "guest access policy" in this question this must be the correct answer. 
Under Guest access you have the possibility to turn of the setting "Make private calls" and "Chat", and this applies to all guest users.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
It is A, D because there is no such a thing as Guest Access Policy. There are Guest Access Settings. Although, the desired effect could also be achieved by modifying the settings (answers B,C), the test authors are obviously checking our attentiveness here.

choices.B: Edit the guest access policy to disable calls.
choices.C: Edit the guest access policy to disable chat.
choices.D: Create and assign a messaging policy for guest users.
choices.A: Create and assign a calling policy for guest users.

choices.C: Confirm that the organization complies with Azure Active Directory configuration policy.
choices.A: Ensure that the date and time for the user's device are correct.
choices.B: Ensure that the user is connected to the internet and that the firewall and other apps are not preventing access.
